{{Globalize|date=April 2018}} [[File:Mathematics lecture at the Helsinki University of Technology.jpg|thumb|Students attend a lecture at a tertiary institution, Helsinki University of Technology.]]
'''Tertiary education,''' also referred to as '''third stage, third level, '''and''' postsecondary education,''' is the educational level following the completion of a school providing a [[secondary education]]. The [[World Bank]], for example, defines tertiary education as including universities as well as trade schools and colleges.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/tertiaryeducation#what_why|title=Tertiary Education|work=World Bank|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en}}</ref> [[Higher education]] is taken to include [[undergraduate]] and [[postgraduate education]], while [[vocational education]] beyond secondary education is known as ''[[further education]]'' in the [[United Kingdom]], or ''[[continuing education]]'' in the [[United States]].
Tertiary education generally culminates in the receipt of [[Academic certificate|certificate]]s, [[diploma]]s, or [[academic degree]]s.
The UNESCO stated that tertiary education focuses on learning endeavors in specialized fields. It includes academic and higher vocational education.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://uis.unesco.org/node/334812|title=Tertiary education (ISCED levels 5 to 8)|website=uis.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref>
The [[World Bank]]'s 2019 [[World Development Report]] on the future of work <ref>[http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/816281518818814423/pdf/2019-WDR-Report.pdf World Bank World Development Report 2019: The Changing Nature of Work.]</ref> argues that given the future of work and the increasing role of technology in value chains, tertiary education becomes even more relevant for workers to compete in the labor market.
== In the United Kingdom == "Tertiary education" includes [[further education]] (FE), as well as [[higher education]] (HE). Since the 1970s specialized FE colleges called “tertiary colleges” have been set up to offer courses such as [[A Levels]], that allow progression to HE, alongside vocational courses. An early example of this which expanded in September 1982 as part of a reorganization of education in the [[Halesowen]] area which also saw three-tier education axed after just 10 years in force.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lambert|first=Tim|title=A Brief History of Dudley, England |url=http://www.localhistories.org/dudley.html|work=A World History Encyclopedia|accessdate=15 September 2011}}</ref>
In some areas where schools do not universally offer sixth forms, tertiary colleges function as a sixth form college as well as a general FE college.
Unlike sixth form colleges, the staff join lecturers' rather than teachers' unions.
Under [[devolution in the United Kingdom]], education is administered separately in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. In 2018 the Welsh Government adopted the term "tertiary education" to refer to post-16 education and training in Wales.<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://gov.wales/about/cabinet/cabinetstatements/2018/Nextsteps/?lang=en |title= Welsh Government {{!}} Written Statement - Public Good and a Prosperous Wales – Next steps |website= gov.wales |language=EN |access-date= 2018-06-07}}</ref>
== In Australia == {{Main|Tertiary education in Australia}} Within Australia "Tertiary Education" refers to continuing studies after a students [[Higher School Certificate (New South Wales)|Higher School Certificate]]. It also refers to any education a student receives after final compulsory schooling, which occurs at the age of 17 within Australia. Tertiary Education options include [[University]], [[Technical and further education|TAFE]] or private colleges.
== In the United States of America == The [[Higher education in the United States|higher education system in the United States]] is decentralized and essentially independent from regulation by the federal government. It is diverse because there are private and public institutions. Some are small and affiliated with religious organizations. Others could be secular, rural, urban, or suburban. In short, there are a wide variety of options which are often locally determined. The United States Department of Education presents a broad-spectrum view of tertiary education and detailed information on the nation's educational structure, accreditation procedures, and connections to state as well as federal agencies and entities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nces.ed.gov/|title=National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) Home Page, part of the U.S. Department of Education|website=nces.ed.gov|language=EN|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref>
The Carnegie Classifications of Institutions of Higher Education provides an explanation so people will understand how American institutions of higher learning compare to each other. The Carnegie platform separates all accredited schools that give out degrees into categories that describe highest degree granted or special areas of study.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.carnegiefoundation.org/newsroom/news-releases/iu-research-center-house-carnegie-classification-institutions-higher-education/|title=IU research Center to House Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education {{!}} Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching|date=2014-10-07|work=Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching|access-date=2018-07-02|language=en-US}}</ref> US tertiary education includes various non-profit organizations promoting professional development of individuals in the field of higher education and helping expand awareness of related issues like international student services and complete campus internationalization.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://educationusa.state.gov/foreign-institutions-and-governments/understanding-us-higher-education|title=Understanding U.S. Higher Education|date=2015-01-08|work=EducationUSA|access-date=2018-07-02|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.acenet.edu/Pages/default.aspx|title=The American Council on Education|website=www.acenet.edu|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref>
== In the European Union == Although tertiary education in the [[European Union|EU]] includes university, it can differ from country to country.
=== In France === Along with IUT and STS, Universities (French: Universités) are tertiary educations.
After going to [[Elementary school]] (French: École maternelle), [[Primary school]] (French: École primaire), [[College]] (French: Collège), and [[Lycee]] (French: Lycée), a student may go to university, but may also [[Retirement|retire]] at that point.

Saeed Ahmed Ghobash |vice_chancellor=Professor Mohamed Albaili |provost =Professor Ghaleb Ali Al Hadrami Al Breiki |president = |undergrad = 14,894 |postgrad = 676 |faculty = |staff = |city = [[Al Ain]] |country = [[United Arab Emirates]] |campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] |mascot = |colors = |website = {{URL|http://www.uaeu.ac.ae/}} }}
'''United Arab Emirates University''' (in [[Arabic language|Arabic]]:جامعة الإمارات العربية المتحدة) is the oldest university in the [[United Arab Emirates]]. It was established after independence from Britain by then the president and the founding father of the [[UAE]], the late [[Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan|Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan]], in 1976. It is the first and oldest of the three government-sponsored institutions of higher learning in the [[United Arab Emirates]] (the other two are the [[Higher Colleges of Technology]] and [[Zayed University]]). The university is located in [[Al Ain]], United Arab Emirates. The UAEU is an accredited research-based institution. Its alumni have provided the [[United Arab Emirates]] with ministers, diplomats, senior government officials, and business leaders.
==Location== The university is located in the city of [[Al Ain]], an oasis city in the [[Emirate of Abu Dhabi|Abu Dhabi]] emirate 140 km east of the capital city of Abu Dhabi and a similar distance from the city of [[Dubai]]. The university features six separate smaller campuses.<ref name=Campus>{{cite web|title=Campus|url=http://www.uniandi.com/?p=university_home&univid=83&lang=en|publisher=Uniandi|accessdate=28 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020172011/http://www.uniandi.com/?p=university_home&univid=83&lang=en|archive-date=20 October 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Students == Students come from all [[Emirates of the United Arab Emirates|seven Emirates]] plus more than 64<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.uaeu.ac.ae/en/flipbooks/annual_report/pdf/annual_report_en.pdf|title = UAEU Fact Sheet|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> countries. 6,696 students live on campus. 2014, enrolled international students constituted 25% of the total enrolled students<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.uaeu.ac.ae/en/flipbooks/annual_report/pdf/annual_report_en.pdf|title = UAEU Fact sheet|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==Rankings== The United Arab Emirates University is continuously ranked as the top university in the [[United Arab Emirates]], and the 4th in the [[Gulf Cooperation Council|GCC]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.uaeu.ac.ae/en/en_uaeu_fact_sheet.pdf|title = UAEU|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The university is ranked as the 6th in the Arab region,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Top 10 Universities in the Arab Region 2015|url = http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings-articles/arab-region-university-rankings/top-10-universities-arab-region-2015|website = Top Universities|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> the 338th and 370th in the world in the 2011/2012 and 2012/2013 [[QS World University Rankings]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://topuniversities.com/university/unitedarabemiratesuniversity/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=9 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101006040141/http://www.topuniversities.com/university/unitedarabemiratesuniversity/ |archivedate=6 October 2010 }}</ref> The 2011/12 QS World University Rankings placed UAEU among the Top 50 Under 50,<ref>{{cite web|title=The QS top 50 universities under 50 2012|url=https://www.theguardian.com/higher-education-network/2012/may/29/top-50-universities-under-50-2012|website=The Guardian|accessdate=11 September 2015}}</ref> i.e., among the top 50 world universities that were founded within the past 50 years, being ranked number 48. Within the Top 50 Under 50 rankings, only eight universities in the world that are younger than UAE are ranked above UAE.
In its capacity as a business school, UAEU was placed as the third best business school in Africa and the Middle East in the 2010 [[QS Global 200 Business Schools Report]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.topmba.com/mba-rankings/top-business-schools-report-2010/regions/top-business-schools-in-africa-and-middle-east|title=Top Business Schools in Africa & the Middle East|work=TopMBA|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> As a research university the UAEU is ranked as number one in the GCC countries, number two in the Arab World, and ninth in the Muslim world. It was ranked the best 86th university in Asia by Times higher education:Asia university ranking <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/world-university-rankings/2012-13/regional-ranking/region/asia|title=Asia University Rankings 2013 top 100|work=Times Higher Education|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
==Management and structure== The Vice-Chancellor is responsible for the management of the university as well as policy and strategic planning, budget and financial activities, external relations, and alumni. The Provost is the Chief Academic Officer responsible for the Colleges, undergraduate studies, research and graduate studies, and information technology. He is assisted by the Deputy Provost. The Secretary General is responsible for services that support the academic mission of the university including finance, budget, facilities management, human resources, auxiliary services, and safety. The Deans are the heads of the academic colleges, which are groupings of academic disciplines, through which the academic staff teach at undergraduate and post graduate levels, and conduct research and scholarship.
The UAEU has undergraduate and postgraduate degree programs in nine colleges: *College of Business and Economics *College of Education *College of Engineering *College of Food and Agriculture *College of Humanities and Social Sciences *College of Information Technology *College of Law *College of Medicine and Health Sciences *College of Science
The University Foundations Program prepares students for academic degree programs with pre-university courses in English, Arabic and Mathematics and other support in making the transition from school to university.
In addition to undergraduate and graduate programs, the UAEU conducts continuous education courses and vocational certificates for the community across all disciplines and hosts the Emirates Health Services, which provides medical skills training.
==Symposiums==
===Biological Sciences===
In November 2016, the University held its first ever symposium on Biological Sciences "GENOMICS & BIOINFORMATICS" attended by experts from different parts of the world.<ref>http://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates-international/1395303227679.html</ref>
==Research== The university launched the first PhD program at a national university in the UAE. As a research institution it attracts national, international, and industrial grants. PhD programs and professional doctorate degrees cover a range including Pharmacy, Public Health, and a Doctorate of Business Administration.
The university hosts research centers including the Zayed Center for Health Sciences and the National Water Center.
== Notable alumni == * [[Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], deputy prime minister and minister of presidential affairs of the [[United Arab Emirates]] * [[Saif bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], minister of interior and deputy prime minister of the [[United Arab Emirates]] * [[Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], minister of foreign affairs of the [[United Arab Emirates]] * [[Hamdan bin Mubarak Al Nahyan]], minister of [[Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (UAE)|Higher Education and Scientific Research]] of the [[United Arab Emirates]] * [[Hamdan bin Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan|Hamdan bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], former minister of foreign affairs of the [[United Arab Emirates]] and former deputy prime minister * [[Ahmed bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], former managing director of [[Abu Dhabi Investment Authority]], was regarded as the 27th most powerful person in the world by ''Forbes in 2009 before his death''<ref>{{Cite web|title = The World's Most Powerful People - Forbes.com|url = https://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/20/power-09_The-Worlds-Most-Powerful-People_Rank_2.html|website = www.forbes.com|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> * [[Maryam Mohammed Khalfan Al Roumi|Maryam Al Roumi]], minister of social affairs of the United Arab Emirates and the second woman to hold a cabinet post in the history of [[United Arab Emirates]], listed among top 10 most powerful Arab women in government by Forbes<ref name="en-maktoob.news.yahoo.com">{{Cite web|title = The most influential Arab women in government|url = https://en-maktoob.news.yahoo.com/the-most-influential-arab-women-in-government-115043690.html|website = Yahoo Maktoob News|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> * Sagr Ighbash, minister of labour of the [[United Arab Emirates]] and former ambassador to the United States of America and Mexico * [[Abdul Rahman Mohammed Al Oweis|Abdul Rahman Al Oweis]], minister of health in the [[United Arab Emirates]] * [[Fatima Al Jaber]], first woman to be elected to the Abu Dhabi Chamber of Commerce board of directors in December 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 100 most powerful Arab women 2012|url = http://www.arabianbusiness.com/100-most-powerful-arab-women-2012-448295.html?view=profile&itemid=448163|website = Arabian Business|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> As of 2014, she is listed as the 94th most powerful woman in the world by ''Forbes''<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Most Powerful Women In Business|url = https://www.forbes.com/pictures/geke45gi/fatima-al-jaber/|website = www.forbes.com|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> * Amal Al Qubaisi, first woman to be elected to the [[UAE]]’s [[Federal National Council]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = First woman appointed to Abu Dhabi Executive Council {{!}} The National|url = http://www.thenational.ae/uae/government/first-woman-appointed-to-abu-dhabi-executive-council|website = www.thenational.ae|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> first woman appointed to [[Executive Council of Abu Dhabi|Abu Dhabi Executive Council]]<ref name="en-maktoob.news.yahoo.com"/> * [[:de:Najla al-Qasimi|Najla Al Qassimi]], UAE's first female ambassador, ambassador of the United Arab Emirates to Portugal, former ambassador to Sweden * [[Essa Abdulla Al Basha Al Noaimi|Essa Al Basha Al Noaimi]], ambassador of the United Arab Emirates to the [[Islamic Republic of Pakistan]] * [[Salma Hareb]], Chief Executive Officer at [[Jebel Ali Free Zone|Jafza]] (Dubai free zone), the first female in the Middle East and North Africa to be appointed head of an economic free zone,<ref>{{Cite web|title = 100 Most Powerful Arab Women 2011|url = http://www.arabianbusiness.com/100-most-powerful-arab-women-2011-384182.html?view=profile&itemid=383757|website = Arabian Business|accessdate = 2015-10-20}}</ref> ranked as the 2nd most powerful Arab woman in government by Forbes<ref name="en-maktoob.news.yahoo.com"/> * [[Mariam al-Mansouri|Mariam Al Mansouri]], first woman to fly combat fighters in UAE * [[Noura Al Kaabi]], member of the [[Federal National Council|Federal National Council of the United Arab Emirates]] and CEO of [[twofour54]] and of the Media Zone Authority Abu Dhabi. * [[Abdul Qader Al Rais]], Emirati artist

{{Refimprove|date=September 2010}} '''University Admissions Finland''' (UAF) is a centralised application service for international Master's degree student applicants for eleven [[Finland|Finnish]] [[Universities in Finland|universities]].
University Admissions Finland processes the applications, which includes credential evaluation and verification of language skills. After UAF’s processing, the universities will do the academic evaluation of the applications and carry out student selections. The admission requirements are set by the universities.
Universities using UAF application service: *[[Hanken School of Economics]]<ref>http://www.hanken.fi/public/en/</ref> *[[Lappeenranta University of Technology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lut.fi/en/lut/pages/default.aspx|title=Lappeenranta University of Technology - LUT|website=www.lut.fi}}</ref> *[[University of Eastern Finland]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uef.fi/studies/|title=Studies - UEF|website=www.uef.fi}}</ref> *[[University of Helsinki]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/admissions/index.html|title=How to apply - University of Helsinki|date=15 November 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[University of Jyväskylä]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jyu.fi/en/studywithus|title=Study with us at the University of Jyväskylä — English|website=www.jyu.fi}}</ref> *[[University of Lapland]]<ref>http://www.ulapland.fi/InEnglish/Admissions/Apply_Now/For_Master_Studies.iw3</ref> *[[University of Oulu]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.degree.oulu.fi/|title=International Master's Programmes|website=www.degree.oulu.fi}}</ref> *[[University of Tampere]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uta.fi/english/introduction.html|title=University - University of Tampere|website=www.uta.fi}}</ref> *[[University of Turku]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utu.fi/en/|title=University of Turku|website=www.utu.fi}}</ref> *[[University of Vaasa]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uva.fi/en/|title=University of Vaasa|date=3 May 2012|website=www.uva.fi}}</ref> *[[Åbo Akademi University]]<ref>http://www.abo.fi/student/en/</ref>

'''WeatherReadyFest''', formerly WeatherFest, is an annual public educational outreach event hosted by the [[National Weather Association]] in conjunction with the organization's annual meeting.
The event includes hands on activities and exhibits focused on atmospheric sciences and disaster safety. Emergency services and area broadcasters display large vehicles. Celebrity meteorologists including [[Weather Center Live|Nick Walker]] and [[Jim Cantore]], from The Weather Channel, [[Ginger Zee]] from Good Morning America and [[James Spann]] were featured at recent events. Exhibitors include the National Weather Service, emergency services, public safety and first responders universities, FedEx, the Air Force, and NASA.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kmov.com/story/38961507/weatherreadyfest-arrives-in-st-louis-to-teach-severe-weather-preparedness|title=WeatherReadyFest arrives in St. Louis to teach severe weather preparedness|last=Mohs|first=Marielle|date=|work=KMOV|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://weatherreadyfest.com/?p=427|title=WeatherReady Fest Welcomes Our Special Guest: Ginger Zee : WeatherReady Fest|website=weatherreadyfest.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-27}}</ref>
The event was first held in Birmingham in 2011 with over 3,400 in attendance.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://weatherreadyfest.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/2018-Prospectus.pdf|title=WeatherReadyFest 2018|last=|first=|date=|website=National Weather Association Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> More than 7,500 attended the event in Saint Louis in 2018. Similar events have been sponsored by the [[American Meteorological Society]] during their annual meeting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/tae/?n=wxfestabout|title=About WeatherFest|last=Service|first=US Department of Commerce, NOAA, National Weather|website=www.crh.noaa.gov|language=EN-US|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref>
== Past events ==
* 2011 [[McWane Science Center|McWayne Science Center]], Birmingham, Alabama<ref name=":0" /> * 2016 [[Nauticus]], Norfolk, Virginia<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.visitnorfolk.com/articles/post/come-enjoy-a-free-day-of-fun-at-weatherready-fest-at-nauticus/|title=WeatherReadyFest at Nauticus|last=|first=|date=2016-09-08|work=Norfolk Convention & Visitors Bureau|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://pilotonline.com/news/local/environment/article_19d3262e-0bbd-576d-af4f-ec0b215453c3.html|title=National Weather Association to hold free weather festival this weekend in Norfolk|last=Mayfield|first=Dave|work=Virginian-Pilot|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en}}</ref> * 2017 [[Discovery Cube Orange County|Discovery Cube]], Santa Ana, California<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://oc.discoverycube.org/event/weatherfest/|title=WeatherReady Fest|last=|first=|date=|work=Discovery Cube OC|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en-US}}</ref> * 2018 [[Saint Louis Science Center]], Saint Louis, Missouri

Email: secretary@waac-us.org |website=http://cool.conservation-us.org/waac/ }}
'''The Western Association for Art Conservation''' ('''WAAC''') is a nonprofit regional membership [[List of conservation organizations|organization]] for [[Conservation-restoration|conservation]] professionals based in the [[Western United States]], although membership is open to all irrespective of geographical location.
==Aims== WAAC serves its members, who have a professional responsibility for the preservation of [[cultural heritage]], and disseminates information through its publications and annual meeting/conference. WAAC advances knowledge, practice and standards for the [[Art conservation|conservation]] profession.
WAAC's bylaws<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cool.conservation-us.org/waac/bylaws.html |title=WAAC Bylaws. Revised 6/29/87, 10/8/96 and 11/15/99 |publisher=Cool.conservation-us.org |date=2008-12-02 |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> state that the specific purposes of WAAC are: * To provide an organization that advances the knowledge of conservation and improves the methods of conservation needed to protect, preserve, and maintain the condition and integrity of objects, structures, or sites that, because of their history, significance, rarity, or quality of work, have a commonly accepted value and importance for the public interest. * To expand knowledge of all subjects related to the conservation of artistic, historic, and other cultural property. * To encourage education, study, and research in the conservation of artistic, historic, and other cultural property. * To promote proficiency and skill in the practice of the conservation of artistic, historic, and other cultural property. * To maintain and promote professional relationships, standards of practice, and ethics for conservators, and to oppose any influences that would tend to lower such standards and ethics. * To organize and otherwise participate in exhibitions dealing with the conservation of artistic, historic, and other cultural property. * To publish, sell, circulate, and distribute books, magazines, publications, literature, films, magnetic tapes, and digital media dealing with the conservation of artistic, historic, and other cultural property. * To solicit funds and to receive donations and legacies. To execute the expenditure of grant monies. * To take all action necessary or desirable in order to accomplish any of the purposes of WAAC, provided that such action is in conformity with the provisions of the California Law, Revenue and Taxation Code, Section 23701d, or the Federal Internal Revenue Code, Section 501(c)(3).
==History== WAAC was founded in 1975 to bring together conservators practicing in the western United States to exchange ideas, information and news.
One of the prime forces behind the creation of the Western Association for Art Conservation, or Western Association of Art Conservators as it was initially called, was Benjamin Bishop Johnson,<ref>{{cite web |first=James L. |last=Greaves|title= A Remembrance: Benjamin Bishop Johnson |work=WAAC Newsletter |volume= 13, Number 1 |date=January 1991 |page=10 |url=http://cool.conservation-us.org/waac/wn/wn13/wn13-1/wn13-104.html |publisher=Cool.conservation-us.org |accessdate= }}</ref> who served as the first President of the organization; and at the time was Chief Conservator at [[LACMA]], as well as a lecturer at [[UCLA]].

==Publications==
===Membership Directory===
A membership directory is published annually and sent to members. The membership directory is alternatively available to members in electronic format; as a pdf. WAAC's Membership Directory is distributed in March of each year.
===Newsletter===
The WAAC Newsletter (ISSN 1052-0066)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sfx.ub.rug.nl:9003/sfx_local/cgi/core/azlist_ver3/a-z_retrieve.cgi/default?&param_sid_save=1e21d737fb1e6c605729ea9b533e118b&param_lang_save=eng&param_letter_group_save=N&param_perform_save=searchTitle&param_letter_group_script_save=Latin&param_chinese_checkbox_save=0&param_services2filter_save=getFullTxt&param_current_view_save=table&param_pattern_save=&param_jumpToPage_save=9&param_type_save=browseLetterGroup&param_textSearchType_save=contains&&lang=eng&function=get_info&obj_id=110978979592847&issn=1052-0066&profile=default&exclude_issn=&exclude_auth=&exclude_note=&exclude_lccn=&exclude_coden=&exclude_availability=&exclude_categories= |title=RUG Links. Find e-Journal. Search: ISSN 1052-0066 |publisher=Sfx.ub.rug.nl:9003 |date=2004-05-30 |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> has been published since 1979, and is published three times per year, in January, May and September. Each issue has been 28-32 pages long. Each issue contains several feature articles, many of which are widely [[Kruithof curve|cited]], and the newsletter is a widely referenced resource for heritage professionals.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Fine Arts Organization, Inc. Online Resources for Collectors |year=2011 |url=http://www.tfaoi.com/aa/4aa/4aa215q.htm |publisher=Tfaoi.com |accessdate= }}</ref>
Regular columns include: * Letter from the President * Regional News * Technical Exchange * Health & Safety * Articles You May Have Missed * Publications and Audiovisual * Conference Reviews * Positions Available
A 10-Year Cumulative Index of the WAAC Newsletter (1979-1988, Volumes 1-10) has also been produced. Back issues are also available online.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cool.conservation-us.org/waac/wn/ |title=WAAC Newsletter |publisher=Cool.conservation-us.org |date= |accessdate=2012-02-16}}</ref>
====Hurricane Katrina====
In response to [[Hurricane Katrina]] WAAC published a special issue of the WAAC Newsletter, September 2005 (vol 27, no 3),<ref>{{cite web |title=WAAC Newsletter, Special Issue: Salvage and Emergency response |date=September 2005 |volume= 27, no 3 |url= http://cool.conservation-us.org/waac/ttl/wn27-3-special.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Cool.conservation-us.org |accessdate= }}</ref> devoted to issue of salvage and emergency response. The issue included information on health and safety for salvage operations, a reprint with a new introduction of Betty Walsh's "Salvage Operations for Water Damaged Archival Collections" and the "Salvage at a Glance" chart<ref>{{cite web |first=Betty |last=Walsh |title=Salvage at a Glance chart. © Province of British Columbia 1997. Published as an insert to the WAAC Newsletter, Vol. 19, No. 2 (May 1997) |url=http://cool.conservation-us.org/waac/ttl/wn27-3-salvage_at_a_glance.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Cool.conservation-us.org |accessdate= }}</ref> (printed on waterproof synthetic paper), as well as a collection of new information and reprinted materials from a number of sources.
===A Guide to Handling Anthropological Museum Collections===
The WAAC publication ''A Guide to Handling Anthropological Museum Collections''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/guide-handling-anthropological-museum-collections/dp/B0006OX0KC |title=A guide to handling anthropological museum collections: Nancy Odegaard: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-16}}</ref> is available in both [[English language|English]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]] (Guía para el manejo de colecciones antropológicas de museos).
The guide has also been translated into [[Arabic language|Arabic]]. Although not directly available from WAAC, it is reportedly widely distributed in the Arab speaking world.<ref>http://www.statemuseum.arizona.edu/research/rebuilding_iraq_culture.shtml</ref>
This is a humorous guide to the "do's and don'ts" of collections handling, and was written by Nancy Odegaard and illustrated by Grace Katterman. It is soft bound, and runs to 41 pages.

==Annual Meeting==
WAAC holds an annual meeting, also referred to as a conference.<ref>{{cite magazine |first=D. |last=Cull |title=Review of Western Association for Art Conservation (WAAC) Annual Meeting |publisher=E-conservation magazine, No. 16 |date=2010 |page= 13-16 |url= http://www.e-conservationline.com/content/view/943 |accessdate= }}</ref> Information about past meetings can be found on the WAAC website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cool.conservation-us.org/waac/historical/pastmeetings/ |title=Index of /waac/historical/pastmeetings |publisher=Cool.conservation-us.org |date= |accessdate=2012-02-16}}</ref>
In 2009 rain water entered the Alaska State Archives building, when a storm ripped the roof from the building, WAAC members who "serendipitously happen to be in [[Juneau, Alaska|Juneau]] for the Western Association for Art Conservation conference"<ref>{{cite web |first=Jeremy |last=Hsieh |title=Rain soaks state archives: Hundreds of boxes of historical documents affected by roof mishap |publisher=Juneauempire.com |date= August 18, 2009 |url=http://juneauempire.com/stories/081809/loc_482967124.shtml |accessdate= }}</ref> assist with the rescue efforts. The conference went ahead, and included a public lecture by Yosi Pozeilov about pinhole cameras.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Juneauempire.com |title= Yosi Pozeilov to give pinhole photography presentation |date=August 16, 2009 |url=http://juneauempire.com/stories/081609/nei_482255766.shtml |accessdate= }}</ref>
